div.l: Therfore his mayster yaf hym a quytaunce
And bad him go wyth sorowe and myschaıı̄unce
And thus this Ioly prentis had his leue
Now let hym ryot all the nyghte or leue
¶And for ther is no theyf wythout a lowke
That helpyth hym to waste and to sowke
Of that he brybe can or borow may
Anon he sent his bed and his aray
Vnto a compyere of his owne sorte
That loueth dyse ryot and dysporte
And hadde a wyf that helde for countenannce
A shop and swyued for her sustenaunce
Here endeth the cokys tale ·
and be ginneth the man of lawes prologe
OVr host sawe well þᵗat by the bryght sonne
The ark of his artifyciall day had rōnne
The fourth part and half an houre and more
And though he were not deppest stert in lore
He wyste well it was the xviij day
Of aprill that is messenger to may
And sawe well that the shadow of euery tre
Was as in lengthe of the same quantyte
That was the body erect that causyd it
And therfore by the shadowe he toke his wyt
That phebus whyche þᵗat shon so clere ⁊and bryght
Degrees was xlv clomben on heyght
And for that daye as in latitude
It was ten of the clocke he gan conclude
And sodenly he plyght his hors abowte
¶ Lordynges quod he I warne you all þˢ rowte
The fourth part of this daye is goon
Now for the loue of god and saynt Iohn
Lese no tyme as ferforth as ye maye
Lordynges the tyme wastith both nyght ⁊and day
And stelyth fro vs what preuely slepyng
And what thrugh neclygence in our wakynge
As doth the streme that turneth neuer agayn
Descendyng fro the mountayn in to the playn
Well can senek and many a phylosopher
Bewayles tyme more than golde in cofer
For losse of catell maye recoueryd be
But losse of tyme shendyth vs quod he
It wyll not come ayen wythouten drede
Nomore than woll malkynes maydenhede
Whan that she hath lost it in her wantonnesse
Let vs not mollen thus in ydylnesse
Syre yre man of lawe quod he so haue ye blys
Tell vs a tale anon as forward is
Ye be submytted thrugh your fre assent
To stonde in this caas at my Iugement
Acquyte you now of your beheste
Than haue ye do your deuoyr at leest
¶ Hoost quod he depardieux Ic assent
To breke forwarde is not myn entent
Beheste is dette and I wolde hold fayn
Alle my behest I can no better sayn
For suche lawe as man geuyth a nother wyght
He sholde hym self vse it by ryght
Thus woll our text but netheles certeyn
I can ryght now no thryfty tale sayn
That chaucer though he can but lewdly
On metris and on rymynge craftely
Hath sayd hem in suche englyssh as he can
Of olde tyme as knoweth many a man
And yf he ne hath sayd hem leue brother
In o boke he hath sayd hem in a nother
For he hath tode of louers vp and doun
Mo than ouyde made of mencyoun
In his epistles that ben full olde
What shold I telle hem syth they be tolde
In yongth he made of ceys and alcyon
And syth he hath spoken of euerychon
Thyse noble wyues ⁊and thyse noble louers eke
Who so that woll his large volume seke
Clepyd the sayntis lyues of cupyde
Ther may he se the large woundis wyde
Of lucrece and of babylone tysbe
The swerd of dydo for the fals enee
The tree of phylles for her demophon
The playnte of dyanere and of hermyon
Of adryane and eke of ysiphyle
The bareyn yle stondynge in the see
The dreyent lyandre for his erro
The terys of eleyne and eke the wo
Of Briseyde and of ladomea
The cruelte of the quene medea
The lytyll chyldren hangyng by the hals
For thy Iason that was of loue so fals
